results.title: Wake up call
results.creator_credit: Jack Pearce, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Jack Pearce may have missed the war, there was still plenty of dangerous work for him to do, clearing mines up the Queensland coast for the Australian Navy.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.brief_description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.
description_for_label: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

results.title: Packages from home
results.creator_credit: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Dave Piggott went to fight in the Vietnam War at 19, it was a very different world to life back in Australia. With the help of the friends he made in the army, he soon got used to life there and it’s the funny stories and good friends that remain with him today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with Jack Jones
results.brief_description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.
results.description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.

Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.

results.title: An Interview with Frank Cox
results.brief_description: Frank Cox signed up to joined the army to see what they had in store for him. He started work as a dispatch rider in Palestine and finished up in the Suez Canal as part of his training. After serving in Tobruk and Greece, Cox became a prisoner of war and has borne witness to the suffering of his colleagues.
results.description: Frank Cox signed up to joined the army to see what they had in store for him. He started work as a dispatch rider in Palestine and finished up in the Suez Canal as part of his training. After serving in Tobruk and Greece, Cox became a prisoner of war and has borne witness to the suffering of his colleagues.

After serving in Tobruk and Greece, Cox became a prisoner of war and has borne witness to the suffering of his colleagues.

results.title: The Long road to independence
results.creator_credit: Mohammed Abdur Rahman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Serving in the Australian army in East Timor, Mohammed Abdur Rahman and his fellow soldiers were attacked by the Indonesian army many times and involved in some highly publicized events. Over time, Rahman became quite connected to the nation and its people, performing humanitarian work and witnessing East Timor’s struggle towards independence.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mohammed Abdur Rahman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Serving in the Australian army in East Timor, Mohammed Abdur Rahman and his fellow soldiers were attacked by the Indonesian army many times and involved in some highly publicized events. Over time, Rahman became quite connected to the nation and its people, performing humanitarian work and witnessing East Timor’s struggle towards independence.

Over time, Rahman became quite connected to the nation and its people, performing humanitarian work and witnessing East Timor’s struggle towards independence.

results.title: Growing up fast
results.creator_credit: John Croxford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It was itchy feet that encouraged John Croxford to join the Australian Navy. He spent most of his time patrolling the Korean coast where there was no room for mistakes.

results.title: All the days of my life
results.creator_credit: Joan Johnstone and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.
results.description: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.

Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.

results.title: Fancy that
results.creator_credit: Joan Johnstone and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: When Joan showed a photo of her new boyfriend to her mother, her mother remarked that he looked a lot like Selby Adams, a british pen friend she wrote to in World War I. Joan served in the Austrlalian Women’s Army Service during World War II and, as a result of that service, was able to re-unite her mother with her pen friend from Britain. An amazing coincidence
results.description: When Joan showed a photo of her new boyfriend to her mother, her mother remarked that he looked a lot like Selby Adams, a british pen friend she wrote to in World War I.
